column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
Radar O'Reilly , 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was a 19 year old soldier in Vietnam. I grew up in the dry desert southwest, and when I was exposed to a humid jungle environment, and diesel fumes and road filth/dust (I was in convoys on an open air gun jeep) I developed allergies due to long-term exposure to some nasty stuff (Agent Orange included)...When I got back to the United States, I was diagnosed by the VA having "chronic allergic rhinitus". As a result, here I am 40 years later with constant post nasal drip which goes into my throat, causing me to constantly clear my throat. I get the worst tickling and gagging sensation in my throat unless I clear it. And when I do so, I get the rudest looks from people when I am out in public (as if I am trying to draw attention to myself...)At the DFW airport late last year while on a brief layover, a woman approached me and asked me if I had ever tried Allegra D. At first I was embarrassed (and a little put-off) but when I got home, I purchased Allegra D and I have found it helps a lot with my ailment (the V.A. has been worthless in helping me, but this over-the-counter drug has been great...) Where Ilive, we have a very nasty tree called the Texas Mountain Cedar, the pollen is nearly toxic! Allegra D helps with this problem, but it isn't perfect for this particular pollen.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: My doctor prescribed Allegra D for my seasonal allergies years ago. I am a type 2 diabeteic who takes Glucotrol xl to controll my blood sugars. Taking Allegra D with Glucotrol caused my blood sugars to drop below 40 for 2 days. I was hospitalized for 3 days put on IV glucose for 3 days and nearly died. There has been no warnings not to take Allegra D if you are on Glucotrol so I want to warn diabetic patients who take oral meds to control thier blood sugars that there could be serious drug interactions. I would have died if I had not been under that hospital care round the clock, I nearly died in the hospital. They had to give me IV boluses og every hour and I was continuously eating and drinking things loaded with glucose and they could not elevate my blood sugars above 50 for 2 days. It took 2 days to completely rid my body of the Allegra D and Glucotrol. I will never take Allegra D again. I have been able to take Zyrtec with no trouble. Today I use a generic for Zyrtec to control my allergies.

column2: zephead, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Allegra-D works.  I don't get drowsy like I do with Zirtec, others. Claritin doesn't work on me. decongestant is best around. I need antihistamine/decongestant for seasonal allergies and occasional bug bite reactions (facial swelling).  Allegra-D keeps me normal, but is expensive.  Generic not on my insurance formulary accepted list.  Why the heck not?  I am not made of $ money.  Otherwise, so far, so good for 5 years now.

column2: theamazingjen, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I was on Allegra for two years before I lost my health insurance. I have severe allergies and was at times unable to function because of stuffy nose, fuzzy head, sneezing, itchy eyes, etc. My only issue with Allegra D 12 hour is that I could only take 1 a day instead of the recommended 2 (12 hours apart of course). Since it is non-drowsy, if I took a dose after about 3pm, I was unable to sleep at night. I did just fine on one dose and my doctor said it was fine as long as I kept taking it and it was working. I recently started a new job and hen my health insurance becomes effective, I hope to get back on Allegra. It is the only allergy medicine that works for me!

column9: First of all, it drives me nuts that you have to take it an hr before meals or 2 hrs after and that you have to take it twice a day.  I could do it in the morning but the later one is harder.....and if I take it close to bedtime, I am awake and restless like crazy.  I never have insomnia...I can fall asleep w/in 5 mins any given night but w/ this med, I am all "nervous" feeling....my legs don't want to be still, I feel a slight increase in heart rate and anxiety....and everytime it happens, I swear I will never take the medicine again!  (until my allergies get really bad, then I cave.)  I was fine on the 24 hr pill (once daily) but this one drives me nuts because I am taking it before bed (well, 2 hrs after dinner).  I am going to ask my Dr for a different Rx.

column2: kathy, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I started taking Allegra D due to regular Allegra wasn't working as well. I started using it every other day with the regular Allegra for about a month, then I was just using 1/2 the dosage everyday of Allegra D.  There were a lot of colds going around and it kept me from getting sick.  However, I started having a gagging sensation in my throat, Review #21 said it best-it felt like there was a ball inside stuck in my throat.  When I would swallow it felt like something large was actually going down the esphogus.  I was having so much discomfort I was taking aspirin to lessen that feeling of pressure, gagging.  This was with drinking a lot of water and only half the dosage.  I decided to stop using it to see if the syptoms decreased.  Maybe a little by the 3rd day.  Went to the doctor, I couldn't take it any more.  She suggested I stop the medication-which I had-and use a vaporizer, and gargle with salt water, she saw my throat was very red.  It helped a little.  After a couple of days I tried the regular Allegra due to the sneezing, etc.  This feeling came right back again.  I never experienced this with just regular Allegra.  It dried up my whole body, so be careful in using this drug.  I took it with apple juice, and it didn't dimenish the effects at all. No nausea.

I take allergy medication year round,  so I knew I would have to try and figure out how to control the side affects.
